abstracts.cdata!:
In the context of the Central Transport
            Corridor Roads Project, the Singida Shelui Road - connecting
            Dar es Salaam with northwestern Tanzania, and with
            landlocked Rwanda, Burundi, and eastern Congo - will be
            upgraded to bitumen standards, to include drainage systems,
            bypassing the hilly section of Sekenke (which cuts across a
            dense forest) so as to prevent deforesation. In order to
            extend sustainable rural production to the road influence,
            promote access, and lower transport costs, the road
            improvements would enhance socioeconomic development,
            including the tourism sector. However, adverse environmental
            impacts, such as soil erosion, loss of farmland, wildlife,
            and natural habitats, as well as air, water and soil
            pollution, in addition to safety and health hazards, call
            for an environmental management to mitigate adversity, as
            follows. To minimize impacts on wildlife, and forests,
            sensitive areas should be realigned by separating road and
            forest with green barriers, and, providing road crossings
            for wildlife by smoothing embankment slopes at regular
            distances, opening river weirs, and large culverts in
            swamplands. The road design should blend in with the
            landscape, avoiding cuts as possible, but stabilizing
            necessary cuts with protective walls, favoring
            re-vegetation. Culverts and cross-drainage should be
            designed to maintain the hydraulic balance, including borrow
            pit excavation and restoration, to avoid stagnation. Soil
            erosion, sedimentation in drainage lines, and cascade
            effects in drains can be minimized by paving drain outlet
            areas with stones and concrete. Road safety measures should
            be in place, as well as the creation of green barriers to
            reduce dust and gas exhaustions.
